Introduction:
Kerbal Space Program is an absolute masterpiece that brings the joy of space exploration and engineering to the gaming world like no other. Developed by Squad, this game has garnered a dedicated fanbase and critical acclaim since its release, and for good reason. Kerbal Space Program offers an unparalleled sandbox experience that encourages players to embrace their inner rocket scientist, embark on awe-inspiring journeys, and celebrate the triumphs of exploration.

Unleash Your Inner Engineer:
One of the most remarkable aspects of Kerbal Space Program is its emphasis on real-world physics and engineering principles. Players are tasked with constructing rockets and spacecraft from the ground up, considering factors like thrust, mass, aerodynamics, and more. This level of detail might sound intimidating, but the game provides an intuitive and rewarding learning curve that helps players grasp these concepts and ultimately feel like true engineers.

Boundless Creativity:
Kerbal Space Program thrives on the boundless creativity it offers players. Whether you're attempting your first suborbital flight or planning an intricate interplanetary mission, the game provides an expansive toolkit of parts, engines, and systems to play with. The sense of accomplishment when you launch a custom-built craft and witness it soar into the heavens is unlike anything else. Every failed attempt is an opportunity to learn, iterate, and improve, fostering an addictive loop of experimentation and success.

Epic Space Exploration:
The game's solar system is a playground of celestial wonders waiting to be explored. From the desolate beauty of the Mun to the distant gas giants, each planet and moon presents its own set of challenges and rewards. Crafting a mission plan, executing gravity assists, and navigating complex orbital mechanics add layers of depth to the gameplay that keep players engaged for hours on end. The sense of wonder that accompanies reaching a new celestial body is truly exhilarating and makes the journey itself as fulfilling as the destination.

Community and Modding:
Kerbal Space Program's vibrant modding community is a testament to its enduring appeal. Thousands of user-generated mods enhance every facet of the game, from adding new parts and features to tweaking realism and visuals. This extends the game's lifespan indefinitely, as players continue to find fresh ways to explore and create. The game's community-driven content cements its status as a game that keeps giving back, encouraging players to share their successes, failures, and discoveries with a like-minded global community.

Educational Value:
Beyond its gaming merits, Kerbal Space Program doubles as an educational tool that effortlessly imparts a wealth of knowledge about space, physics, and engineering. The game turns complex scientific concepts into hands-on experiences, making learning fun and accessible. Players are bound to gain a newfound appreciation for the challenges of space travel and a deeper understanding of the universe we inhabit.

Conclusion:
Kerbal Space Program is a true triumph in the world of gaming, offering an unmatched blend of creative freedom, scientific education, and space exploration. Its ability to inspire players to explore, experiment, and overcome challenges is a testament to its remarkable design. Whether you're a space enthusiast, an aspiring engineer, or simply someone seeking a unique and rewarding gaming experience, Kerbal Space Program is an absolute must-play that will keep you enthralled for countless hours. Embark on a journey of discovery, and let your imagination reach for the stars!

[h1]Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)[/h1]

Kerbal Space Program is an awe-inspiring and educational sandbox adventure that allows players to become space pioneers, managing their own space program and exploring the cosmos with the lovable and quirky Kerbals. With its realistic physics, creative freedom, and boundless exploration possibilities, it stands as one of the most beloved and immersive space simulation games of all time.

[h1]Likes:[/h1]

Realistic Physics and Simulation: Kerbal Space Program offers a realistic physics engine that accurately models the challenges of space travel, providing a rewarding and educational experience for players.

Creative Freedom and Exploration: The game's sandbox mode allows players to design their own rockets, spaceplanes, and missions, encouraging limitless creativity and exploration within the vastness of space.

Educational Value: Kerbal Space Program fosters an appreciation for science, engineering, and problem-solving, making it a valuable tool for learning about space travel and orbital mechanics.

Lovable and Quirky Kerbals: The game's endearing and quirky Kerbal astronauts add a lighthearted and charming element to the space-faring adventure, making players care deeply for their intrepid crew.

Active Modding Community: The game has a dedicated and active modding community, constantly providing new content, enhancements, and challenges to enrich the overall experience.

[h1]Dislikes:[/h1]

Steep Learning Curve: For newcomers to space simulation games, the initial learning curve of mastering rocket design and orbital maneuvers may be challenging, but the sense of achievement is rewarding.

Lack of In-Depth Tutorials: Some players may find that the game's tutorials could be more comprehensive, especially for understanding advanced concepts and mission planning.

In conclusion, Kerbal Space Program is an out-of-this-world sandbox adventure that allows players to embark on their own interstellar odyssey. With its realistic physics, creative freedom, and educational value, it appeals to both space enthusiasts and those seeking a unique and immersive gaming experience. Whether you dream of conquering distant planets, constructing elaborate space stations, or simply launching Kerbals into the cosmos, Kerbal Space Program guarantees a stellar journey through the wonders of space exploration. Embrace your inner rocket scientist, chart your course to the stars, and join the ranks of the intrepid Kerbals in the boundless universe of Kerbal Space Program.

Steam playtime counter lies - after a while, you'll start launching game through CKAN (mod manager) and bypassing Steam.

One of the best sandbox games ever - you get to play with actual(-ish) physics, design your rockets, figure out why nobody likes physics when your rockets explode, rinse and repeat. Game sticks to a simple feedback loop of design-fly-fail what works remarkably well for figuring out what you still don't know. Learning curve past very basics can be steep - depending what you find enjoyable, you might spend more time doing math than actually playing the game... or send little green men to their inevitable doom.

Mods are a must - they make game look better (scatterer), work better (aerodynamics mods) and play better (various QoL). Game is somewhat lacking in more nuanced aspects like life support or part failures - it makes core part (building and flying space vessels) more approachable, but removes some fun constraints those systems create. Find a set of mods you enjoy.

For DLCs: Making History ends up being a pack of new parts if you don't play with missions it adds, Breaking Ground also adds some new game mechanics like ground science that add some stuff to do and plan for.

Kerbal Space Program apparently runs on Intel UHD Graphics 630 so I can recommend this game.

I bought this game because I always wanted to be an astronaut. I thought it would be easy to launch a rocket to space. Boy, was I wrong. It took me a whole day to successfully launch a rocket to space, after watching several tutorials I understood I could make anything in the game. But that also meant I could make anything explode, crash, or get lost in the vastness of space.

The game is very realistic and challenging. You have to deal with gravity, aerodynamics, fuel consumption, orbital mechanics, and more. You also have to manage your crew of adorable green aliens called Kerbals, who have a knack for getting into trouble. Sometimes they will scream in terror as their rocket falls apart. Sometimes they will smile and wave as they drift away into the void. Sometimes they will do both at the same time.

The game is also very rewarding and fun. You can create amazing vehicles and missions, and explore a solar system full of planets and moons. You can land on the Mun, the game's version of the Moon. You can send probes to other worlds and discover secrets and anomalies. You can dock with space stations and rendezvous with asteroids. You can even build bases and colonies on other planets.

The game has a lot of content and replay value. You can play in different modes, such as sandbox, science, or career. You can also download mods and custom parts from the community, which add even more features and possibilities to the game. You can also share your creations and stories with other players online.

Kerbal Space Program is a game that will teach you a lot about science, engineering, and space exploration. It will also make you laugh a lot at your own failures and successes. It's a game that will inspire you to dream big and reach for the stars.

I give this game 5 out of 5 stars. It's one of the best games I've ever played. If you love space, rockets, or Kerbals, you should definitely buy this game.

There are some great moments, when you see your crew smiling as you say to [insert kerbal name] something like.... You can laugh now, but there were no guarantees I would get you down safely.

Yes its enjoyable, yes you have to run through the first few tutorials.
Yes the game is missing substantial information to actually do the Job like a real engineer/astronaut.

the only test is a real test, no computer screens to look at at possible arcs of altitude advancement. 
When you click launch to test your craft from the pad they take you (into another instance) ...into what seems like a separate server around the world from you, upload all the parts, a minute, so slow.

Great I like waiting, launch should be instant it is not. It is like they recreated the hour it takes for the vehicle to make it to the launch pad.....

Career mode takes too long, be prepared to understand what the word grind means.

So to sum up, consider what the word grind means, digest it, roll it around on the tongue a few times, then be prepared to spend your entire life grinding. There is no stroking of ego in this game, it is literally, you failed 100 times now you earn the next piece, ad infinitum until you get all the tech.

Slow is the other way of looking at this game, be prepared to learn and the tutorials are badly integrated with career mode, a tutorial will say this is easy do this, in career mode, it would take you 50-100 hours just to get the tech to get a stable orbit and the tutorial doesn't even show you the ship they used to get to orbit, they just place a ship in orbit already...

Can I recommend, not really, it misses so much of what is required to be an engineer/astronaut to get to space. So they instead delayed your progress with grind.

Even a simple read out of how high should this rocket combination get in altitude would be nice. No, you get no information, you just have to test and save each ship design. No indication of where to go to get intel, you test until you get some, then you go somewhere else and get it, but the scientists do not say we need this or this. It is stupid.

Minimum the scientists should identify where they need science reports from.


So yes many improvements missing before I give a thumbs up.

Out of all the space flight simulators this has to be the best. The physics is accurate (ish), the Kerbals themselves are endearlingly cute and the choice of career, science and sandbox modes makes the out of the box game highly flexible. Then when you have done just about everything you might possibly try there is a huge range of community mods to add which give a whole new dimension to the game.

I would like to see larger rocket components, better in orbit construction options and interstellar options all of which are promised for KSP2 but nowhere in sight yet so for the moment I'm sticking with KSP1 and mods.

This game is a space-physics sim in a different solar systems with aliens called Kerbals There are 5 planets (4 terrestrial 1 gas giant), 2 dwarf planets, and 9 moons to explore with lots of easter eggs. Vessels are constructed from a varitey of rocket parts ranging from 0.625 meter diameter fuel tanks to 3.75 meter tanks. The dlcs can add robotic parts and 5m fuel tanks. There are NO colony mechanics apart from basic fuel mining. This game is addictive with a learning curve to it. The game starts off hard and I didn't really know what to do. Now I can visit any place in the solar system with ease. But that did take 250 hours of playtime. The game itself is very fun, and I will continue to enjoy this game. No more feature updates will be released though.

Cool game, but here's a cooler Chicken Taco recipe:

1 pound boneless skinless chicken thighs
1 teaspoon garlic powder
½ teaspoon onion powder
½ teaspoon cumin
½ teaspoon smoked paprika
½ teaspoon chili powder
½ teaspoon salt
½ teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
Juice of 2 limes
1 tablespoon olive oil
Topping:

⅓ cup finely chopped red or sweet onion
⅓ cup finely chopped cilantro
1 finely chopped jalapeño
Juice of 1 lime
Salt and pepper, to taste
1 lime, cut into 8 pieces
16 small corn tortillas for serving

Instructions:
In a large zipper-topped plastic baggie or in shallow dish, add the chicken, all of the spices, lime juice, and oil. Close the bag and use your hands to mix everything together. If you are using a shallow dish, use tongs to work the spices evenly into the chicken. You can let this rest for up to a half-hour or work with it right away. I like to let it rest a minute to increase the flavor.
Heat a large skillet over medium to medium-high heat. When the skillet is hot, add a tablespoon of oil to the pan and then add the chicken. Cook for 12 to 14 minutes, turning once, until the chicken is cooked through. Remove the chicken from the pan and let it rest for 10 minutes. If you have an extra-large chicken thigh, you'll need to cook them longer, so turn down the heat to medium and cook them until no longer pink (could take up to 25 minutes or 12 minutes per side).
While the chicken cooks, stir together the chicken taco topping by placing the chopped onion, cilantro, jalapeño, and the juice of one lime in a small bowl. Add salt and pepper, and stir to combine.
While the chicken rests, wipe your skillet clean with a warm rag or paper towels, and place the skillet back on the heat over medium-high to high heat. Place two tortillas (still stacked together) on the skillet and cook until the underside starts to char. Flip over and cook the other side (so the middle of each tortilla won't be cooked against the skillet but it will get warm all the way though). Repeat with remaining tortillas.
Chop the rested chicken into bite-sized pieces.
To serve, place ⅛ of the chopped chicken in each set of tortillas (still two stacked together) and top with ⅛ of your onion mixture. Serve each taco with a wedge of lime to squeeze over the taco just before serving.

This game makes the complexities of space travel fun and simple. While the learning curve is steep and getting to orbit for the first time can be a great achievement, the inbuilt and optional tutorials make it less daunting than it was. There is no story goal to follow, just building rockets and exploring. I must admit, exploring can get easily boring as most of the destinations are bland and uninteresting, making the process of getting there the fun part. Trial and error is a major part of the flying, testing, failing, and flying again, so I certainly wouldn't recommend this game to someone who gets frustrated at failure easily. All in all I find it fun building and crashing, and I would recommend it to like minded people.

Kerbal Space Program is a truly exceptional game that ignites the spirit of exploration and scientific discovery within each player. With its unique blend of realistic physics, deep strategic gameplay, and a touch of humor, Kerbal Space Program has captured the hearts and imaginations of space enthusiasts and gamers alike.

One of the standout features of Kerbal Space Program is its attention to scientific accuracy. The game provides a remarkable simulation of real-world physics, offering players an authentic experience as they embark on the journey to conquer the final frontier. From launching rockets into orbit to planning interplanetary missions, every action and decision in Kerbal Space Program requires careful consideration, making it a delightfully challenging and educational experience.

The game's sandbox nature grants players an incredible amount of freedom to design and build their own spacecraft, space stations, and planetary rovers. The construction system is intuitive and robust, allowing for endless experimentation and creativity. As you progress, you'll find yourself iterating on designs, tweaking fuel ratios, and fine-tuning your spacecraft to maximize efficiency and ensure the success of your missions. The sense of accomplishment that comes from launching a well-designed vessel into space is unparalleled.

Beyond its technical depth, Kerbal Space Program is infused with a lighthearted and charming sense of humor. The endearing Kerbals, the game's green, big-headed inhabitants, add a whimsical touch to the experience. Their enthusiasm, coupled with their propensity for hilariously catastrophic failures, brings a smile to your face even in the face of adversity. The game strikes a perfect balance between the seriousness of space exploration and the joy of embarking on daring adventures.

Visually, Kerbal Space Program is a treat for the eyes. The game's colorful and detailed graphics bring the vastness of space and the beauty of celestial bodies to life. From the awe-inspiring sight of distant planets to the intricate details of your spacecraft, the visuals immerse you in the wonder and majesty of the cosmos.

Furthermore, the supportive and passionate community surrounding Kerbal Space Program is a testament to its enduring appeal. The game's modding scene is vibrant, with a wealth of user-created content that expands the game's possibilities even further. From new spacecraft parts to realistic visual enhancements, the mods add a whole new dimension to the already rich gameplay experience, ensuring that there's always something fresh and exciting to explore.

Kerbal Space Program is not just a game; it is a gateway to a world of scientific wonder and exploration. It effortlessly combines education, entertainment, and creativity, offering an experience that is as rewarding as it is enjoyable. Whether you're an aspiring astronaut or a gaming enthusiast looking for a unique and immersive experience, Kerbal Space Program is an absolute must-play. Strap in, blast off, and prepare to embark on an adventure that will take you to the furthest reaches of the cosmos.

Kerbal has a scaled down version of a solar system with realistic orbital physics (no nonsense with spaceships banking and always flying in the direction they are pointing, no warp drives). The game requires you to assemble rockets (and planes) from components and when your career advances you get more components and also improvements to the user interface for planning orbital maneuvers. One chooses to accept missions which get more advanced over time. The game also comes with a set of tutorials which help you to get familiar with building rockets and flying them. I very much enjoy the realistic physics of the game which gives you a better appreciation of space exploration.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

This game is awesome. You build your own rocket ships, satellites, rovers, planes, or whatever it is you want to make and then you fly them. 

The game actually does have a story/campaign mode, but I never bother with that, I like to play sandbox and just make stuff and fly/drive it.

This game will teach you more about orbital mechanics and give you a better intuition than reading textbooks, methinks.

Rocket science isn't that hard, after all.

THE CHRISTIAN PERSPECTIVE

This game does not, insofar as I know, portray blasphemy, murder, idolatry, or any other sin. I know of no explicit portrayals of sin, let alone exalting of it.

I think some of the information screens give an evolutionary explanation for the kerbals' origins and history. The game has evolution-based lore. Evolution is just as fictional as the kerbals are, so I guess it's fine that they used that as an explanation. 

Nevertheless, it's certainly a vocal support of the pseudoscience of our era (the idea that living things are the result of tiny changes over vast eons of unseen time and that the earth and stars are similarly the result of ongoing natural processes) being put right next to real observational science which can be tested and measured (how objects move in space, planets, astronomy, etcetera). 

This ultimately aids in the ideological war being waged by the western atheists to confuse the definition of science (1984 newspeak style) to include their nonsense.

If you are a christian, though, you already know about this war and you know the true history of the world. You are immune. The game's lore isn't why people play this game anyway. It'd be the same game if it had no lore at all.

If your child knows how to think critically and understands the war in our culture going on, which every child should be taught very early on (Remember kids: the disciples saw, felt, and touched Jesus after he rose from the dead, but nobody has ever seen millions of years) then this game's lore is not going to be an issue.

It's a tiny polka dot flaw on an otherwise fantastic game.

When I was little, I wanted to be an astronaut. I watched man land on the moon just weeks before my 2nd birthday, and had a lunar lander on my cake that year. Sadly, that dream never went anywhere. But this game might just be the next best thing. 

Don't get me wrong. This is NOT Call of Duty or Tomb Raider or Final Fantasy whatever. It's not even Mass Effect ... This game is HARD.  It is frustrating. It has an amazingly steep learning curve. It can leave you shaking, or wanting to scream. 

But it is hands down the best game I have ever played.  I am 55, and I have played literally THOUSANDS of games in just about every genre. I have felt terror, when a screaming woman knocked me (literally) out of my chair at 2 am playing DOOM 3 in the dark. I have felt the thrill of taking the checkered flag in Gran Turismo.  Aggression made my blood pound as I give a brutal check in NHL18. But never ... and I mean, NEVER, have I felt a sense of accomplishment, actual accomplishment, while playing a video game. 

This game does that. 

The first time I got a jet I built to fly was a thrill, but landing it left a feeling of accomplishment. 
Launching into orbit is fun, and even challenging. But completing a successful Holman Transfer Maneuver and setting up a stable orbit around the Mun? Man. I am bloody Neil Armstrong! 

Don't be sissy. The game is more than worth it. And there are not only a boatload of tutorials online for, well, everything Kerbal, but there is also a thriving mod community who have pushed the game WAY beyond it's boundaries in terms of content and graphics improvements.

Don't be afraid. There are hundreds of tutorials on YouTube for anything you might need help with, from rocket/plane designs to orbital mechanics and transfer orbits.  And I am unabashedly willing to admit I use them.

All you need is a copy of the game, and some time to realize you're already addicted, you just don't know it yet  ;)

So the original developer studio that developed this game got poached, no doubt it was an IP grab without a care for this game. KSP2 is a poorly optimized, clunky mess. It's sad, because the original team definitely could've delivered results with all the experience they gathered.

KSP2 only has better graphics. Oh but also a new engine! And yet it matters not as of now, the strongest of rigs tank in performance once you build vehicle with "too many" components. But too many compared to this game is a joke.

This game on the other hand runs reasonably well and is stable, there's plenty of content, the game-play is fun and it's charming, the learning curve is a bit steep but there's PLENTY of guides and videos, so you'll be fine. It's educational and it works.

This game massively sucks. We were all tricked, like Goat Simulator, only more insidious.

The physics suck. Don't defend it; it's terrible. Spaceships will sometimes just flop over during flight, even though you built it with snap-to symmetry. You just have to accept that, for whatever reason, the game doesn't want you to fly a spaceship that day -- because come back another time and the very same spaceship designs that were pinwheeling all day, will suddenly work JUST FINE, while the stock ships all start behaving like a pigeon in a tornado.

The gameplay modes all suck. The sandbox mode loses its appeal in a matter of two hours, and the career mode is a slog of depressing proportions. The science mode is supposed to be like a lite version of career mode, but removing the money and micromanagement doesn't improve the game because you're still left with the terrible flight control.

The research tree is the true dealbreaker. Imagine putting a dozen hours into a save file (or more in some cases, depending how involved you get in the building process), launching ships, doing science, landing, collecting points, and researching... only to find that you have researched yourself into a corner, unable to reach new parts of the solar system, and unable to do new science things to collect points for more unlocks.

Imagine if a story-driven game did that, blocking your progress and bricking your save file by letting you spend your skill points in a way that prevents you from winning any more gameplay sequences. You would call it Refund of the Year.

I'm glad this game only wasted ten bucks.

But I am very very done with buying joke games and meme nonsense. I should have learned my lesson with Goat Simulator, but apparently not.

Apollo 1, initially designated AS-204, was the first crewed mission of the Apollo program, the American undertaking to land the first man on the Moon. It was planned to launch on February 21, 1967, as the first low Earth orbital test of the Apollo command and service module. The mission never flew; a cabin fire during a launch rehearsal test at Cape Kennedy Air Force Station Launch Complex 34 on January 27 killed all three crew members—Command Pilot Gus Grissom, Senior Pilot Ed White, and Pilot Roger B. Chaffee—and destroyed the command module. The name Apollo 1, chosen by the crew, was made official by NASA in their honor after the fire.

Immediately after the fire, NASA convened an Accident Review Board to determine the cause of the fire, and both chambers of the United States Congress conducted their own committee inquiries to oversee NASA's investigation. The ignition source of the fire was determined to be electrical, and the fire spread rapidly due to combustible nylon material and the high-pressure pure oxygen cabin atmosphere. Rescue was prevented by the plug door hatch, which could not be opened against the internal pressure of the cabin. Because the rocket was unfueled, the test had not been considered hazardous, and emergency preparedness for it was poor.

During the Congressional investigation, Senator Walter Mondale publicly revealed a NASA internal document citing problems with prime Apollo contractor North American Aviation, which became known as the Phillips Report. This disclosure embarrassed NASA Administrator James E. Webb, who was unaware of the document's existence, and attracted controversy to the Apollo program. Despite congressional displeasure at NASA's lack of openness, both congressional committees ruled that the issues raised in the report had no bearing on the accident.

Crewed Apollo flights were suspended for twenty months while the command module's hazards were addressed. However, the development and uncrewed testing of the lunar module and Saturn V rocket continued. The Saturn IB launch vehicle for Apollo 1, SA-204, was used for the first test flight, Apollo 5. The first successful crewed Apollo mission was flown by Apollo 1's backup crew on Apollo 7 in October 1968.

After 8 years of development the KSP1 interface is still full of annoying bugs and problems. If you are considering KSP2 and wondering when its bugs will be fixed, your answer is clear: NEVER!!!!!

The bugs in Kerbal Space Program are so obvious that it's hard to imagine the developers not knowing about them. For example, if you are landed on the Mun and you use move mode to move a part on your ship, you can't get back to build mode because when you mouse over the build mode button, another menu item un-hides and drops down over top of the build mode button, so you can't push the button. It looks like the play testers just switched to using the hotkeys, problem solved, right? But when a new player starts playing the game they don't know the hotkeys so they're stuck.

Another example is the maneuver nodes, they keep just randomly disappearing in the middle of setting the maneuver and you have to click the little X to make it come back. Then because the handles are so close together you inevitably grab the wrong one and screw up the settings so you have to start over, then it disappears again. This is something you have to do A LOT so it gets really freaking annoying really freaking quick when this happens every time.

Maybe the worst bug is that when you rendezvous in orbit and try to switch from one craft to another, the icon for the craft you are already in is in the way of the one you want to switch to and so you can't select it. Again you have to do this A LOT so it's incredible to me that they didn't bother to fix such an annoying and obvious bug after 8 YEARS. You have to go to the tracking station to switch craft and that causes 2 load screens that are so loooooong that it is actually easier to find the 1-pixel-wide point on the edge of the current ship icon where (if you hold your tongue just right) you might be able to get the other ship icon to intermittently appear and if your timing is perfect you may get the option to "switch to" after only a few dozen tries.

There are plenty more bugs but I have limited space so I only mentioned the most annoying ones. You probably won't enjoy when your apoapsis number suddenly and inexplicably goes negative and breaks the law of physics either. 

The result of all these bugs, is that Kerbal Space Program causes far more frustration and annoyance than fun, which is a shame because there are some fun elements to the game, if the interface would just do what it is told.

In my opinion, these "permanent" bugs are an obvious sign of a lazy development team. They found workarounds instead of fixing the bugs, ignoring the frustration this would cause new players who had not yet discovered the workarounds. There is really no excuse as they've had over 8 years to fix this mess but apparently they chose not to.

I will not be buying KSP 2 or any other title from this developer for the above reasons.

Kerbal Space Program. One of the most advanced space and physics simulators ever created. But yet, even though it is so advanced, it is also so incredibly silly. One day you might feel like playing seriously, and building a serious rocket meant to do serious stuff. Another, you might strap 100 boosters to each other and watch the absurdness you just created play out. That's the beauty of this game, it caters to everyone, whether you have degrees in physics or you just like making silly rockets that go boom. Would I recommend this game? Absolutely. 

(Side note: I have more than 169 hours; it just didn't log all of them for some reason.)

If you are looking for a review on Kerbal Space Program you have come to the wrong place but, I can tell you how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

[h1]Fun with Physics and Little Green People![/h1]
[u]Creators and Tinkerers Will Love This Game[/u]

[b]The Good[/b] – Creation process, humor, different modes, Physics, construction interface, Accessible

[b]The Not so Good[/b] – Graphics, Learning curve, Grind 

[u]Bottom Line[/u] – A truly well-executed, original idea which carved out its own little niche in the gaming community from scratch. Fun, funny, unique, and addictive sandbox with nearly endless possibilities, with something new to explore always right around the corner.

I am not a rocket scientist. If this wasn’t infinitely clear to me when I sat down to play KSP the first time, it became much clearer quickly. My first failure wasn’t spectacular or explosive – It just never left the launch pad. And it wasn’t for lack of trying, either. It was really straining! I also must be the world’s absolute worst about playing a game for only a few minutes or a few hours and then giving up on that game because I “Don’t get it.” It’s at this point games typically end up in my backlog and rarely get played again.
The thing is, after my boring, vanilla rocket failure, I didn’t just chuck the “baby with the bathwater.” I went back to the drawing board and tried again (I think that one exploded) and again (Ran out of fuel) and again (bounced off the atmosphere at reentry). With each try, I honed my skill and learned a little more about the rules of this new star system I’d begun to explore. Learning this way rarely felt like a chore, as it sometimes does with repeated failures in a game, but instead was part of the adventure itself and was, actually, surprisingly fun. There were some missions during which I felt like I’d never get the hang of it, and others I was genuinely frustrated. But everything worth doing has these setbacks sometimes. KSP is absolutely a game worth learning.
I don’t normally do this, but I’ll start with the things about the game that could potentially use improvement because I think the good FAR outweighs the not-so-good. At the top of that list is the graphics. They’re not bad, but they are showing their age. Remember KSP became available for the first time in 2011, so this is to be expected. They’re not bad, but they’re not Elite Dangerous or RDR2. You can probably tell by my first KSP stories that the learning curve in-game is significant. It will probably take you a couple hours to learn the necessary skills to get your crew to the Mun the first time, and maybe more to get safely landed on it and back home. This can feel like a grind sometimes, but that feeling does pass if you give it a chance to.
The really great thing about Kerbal Space Program is that the limit of what you can build and the places you can go depend on you. Just like our own history, the voyage to the moon is just the beginning. There are other astral bodies out there to explore as well. The first step to exploring each of those is to build the right hardware, and the build process itself is fun. Depending on the mode you select for your game, you either start out with every part possible right off the bat (sandbox), or you begin with limited parts and have to earn, research and purchase the others over time (career). If you choose career mode, you can do a good deal with the parts you accumulate as the result of research, but it can take a while before you can “build anything you can imagine.” Eventually, you’ll get there. Just keep plugging away.  In sandbox, the heavens are the limit. You’ll have every part on your first build. I would recommend career mode just for the added structure and tutorial, but that’s going to be about your preference. The humor in the game is a nice diversion from the intensity of your mission/design cadence. If you’re in career mode, plug into these mini-laughs by accepting missions from your mission control building. Those same missions will advance your exploration career if you are in career mode.
The game does manage to make the design/build process a lot of fun. So much fun that just writing this has me wanting to go back and play KSP again. Because the process is fun, it’s very accessible and it’s easy to learn your next step. The build interface is intuitive enough that you can really sit down and start slapping things together right away. Above all of these, I think I like the orbital mechanics best. The physics are really cool. They’re unforgiving, sometimes brutal, and potentially the cause of costly mistakes, but getting to use Kerbal’s gravity to bring your capsule back in from a long journey and see it splash-down safely is almost always an exhilarating experience. You’ll love to slingshot around Mun to travel to Minimus at just the right elevation to avoid the surface while getting as much energy as possible. You may not be a physics nerd like me, but you’ll find something about KSP to love if you give it a try.

[u]Players who may like this:[/u] Sandbox fans, Creators, Physics simulator buffs, Space nerds, Rocket nerds, Self-starters

[u]Similar to these games:[/u] Factorio (Creation, design), No Man’s Sky (Exploration, open world, space)

[u]I would buy at this price:[/u] $30

Left Bill Kerman on the dark side of the moon, and killed seven Kerbals trying to rescue him. 10/10 never got him back.

Day 1: This is Bill Kerman, I have landed safely on the moon and have lost all contact with HQ. My morale is wavering and I'm scared for what's to come, I haven't eaten in hours and I'm completely shaken. The moon is only dark and cold with no air to breathe. HQ please respond! 

Day 2: The moon is only dark and the vessel has kept me warm through hours of rest. I'm starting to get used to this strange environment but I fear there is no air breathable here. I'm also starting to hear strange noises around the vessel that give me chills every time it get louder. This silence is deafening and I have never felt more alone in my life. I'm going to try and make a radio signal to contact HQ again but I'm becoming concerned as their communications has me on edge; there's no noise coming through to tell me what's happening to HQ. 

Day 3: The screams of the dammed are faint but constant.

Day 4: I see a rescue vessel! HQ has not forgotten me! I'm the luckiest man alive right now! I will survive this ordeal and return to my planet. Thank you HQ for all your support, you have saved my life today.

Day 5: I have witnessed the most horrendous thing I have ever seen with my own eyes. Jebediah Kerman, the man I have trained within the training center and the man I am proud to call my hero, has been mysteriously killed by sinking into the moon's soil moments before reaching my vessel. He unexpectedly sped up and accelerated deeply into the soil just seconds after saying "Why am I so slow?" What on Kerban happened? I don't know and neither does HQ. 

Day 7: HQ has sent 3 vessels to attempt to rescue me but all three have resulted in the death of seven Kerbals. The first vessel was the death of Jebediah Kerman, the second vessel crashed by Valetina and the third vessel was some new recruits that crashed in moons orbit. I have sent my last message to HQ informing them to just leave me here, I just don't want any Kerbals to die!

Day 8: The noises are getting worse, someone is screaming in the distance and I can't make out what they are saying.. It's terrifying! Where are they coming from?! I will run out of food soon. The screams of the dammed are faint but constant.

How to make Beef Wellington
Ingredients:
- 1 (2-pound) beef tenderloin
- Salt and freshly ground black pepper
- 2 tablespoons Dijon mustard
- 1/2 pound mushrooms, finely chopped
- 1/4 cup chopped shallots
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 2 tablespoons unsalted butter
- 1/4 cup dry white wine
- 1/4 cup beef broth
- 1 tablespoon chopped fresh thyme leaves
- 1 sheet puff pastry, thawed
- 1 large egg, lightly beaten

Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F.
2. Season the beef tenderloin with salt and pepper.
3. Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the beef and sear on all sides until browned, about 2 minutes per side. Remove from the skillet and let cool.
4. Spread the Dijon mustard over the cooled beef tenderloin.
5. In the same skillet, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the mushrooms, shallots, and garlic and cook until the mushrooms are browned and the liquid has evaporated, about 10 minutes.
6. Add the white wine, beef broth, and thyme to the skillet and cook until the liquid has reduced by half, about 5 minutes.
7. Remove the skillet from the heat and let the mushroom mixture cool.
8. On a lightly floured surface, roll out the puff pastry to a thickness of 1/4 inch.
9. Spread the mushroom mixture over the puff pastry.
10. Place the beef tenderloin on top of the mushroom mixture.
11. Wrap the puff pastry around the beef tenderloin, making sure to seal the edges.
12. Brush the beaten egg over the top of the puff pastry.
13. Place the Beef Wellington on a baking sheet and bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the puff pastry is golden brown and the beef tenderloin is cooked to your liking.
14. Let the Beef Wellington rest for 10 minutes before slicing and serving

[h1]NASA Simulator - Now You Too Can Uncover the Lies of the Space Industry[/h1]

[b]Kerbal Space Program[/b] is the perfect game for those who are tired of being lied to by NASA and the mainstream media. Finally, you can expose the truth for yourself and embark on a mission to the moon with your own spacecraft.

With this game, you'll get to experience what it's like to be a real astronaut, without all the annoying requirements of actually being one. Build your own rockets, test your designs, and launch them into the great unknown. Who knows what you'll find up there, but one thing's for sure: it won't be what they tell you it is.

The game's realistic physics and challenging gameplay will keep you hooked for hours, as you strive to uncover the secrets of space and the universe. And don't worry, you'll have plenty of time to think about the mysteries of the cosmos as you watch your crew slowly suffocate in the cold vacuum of space.

So what are you waiting for? Strap in, launch into orbit, and discover what's really on the far side of the moon. Because in this NASA Simulator, the only thing you can trust is your own wits and determination.

[list]
[*]Build and design your own spacecraft
[*]Test your designs with realistic physics
[*]Embark on missions to the moon and beyond
[*]Expose the lies of the space industry for yourself
[/list]

I've played this game for almost ten years now (Ouch. That hurts to write). It is a meticulously detailed space simulator, and while it doesn't necessarily have any story guiding your hand, it is still quite fun to explore or work up your space program in Career mode if that's your jam. There are some quirks with the game that can be frustrating at times, although some of these can be fixed (If you're not using Autostruts with Advanced Tweakables enabled, you should be). This game has a lot of exploring to do already, but the modding community takes it to another level. You can mod this game until it breaks, and the modding community has come up with everything conceivable from hyper-realism to sillyness. I'm currently using an upscaled planet pack, N-body orbital mechanics, and life support / general systems overhaul mods (JNSQ, Principia, and Kerbalism in particular) among many others, and I've modded KSP into almost a new game many times over the years.

The only thing I don't like about the game is the DLC pricing. It's a bit steep, but you can get the complete edition on sale for less than $30, and it's easily worth that price if its up your alley. KSP 2 is on the horizon at the time of writing, but it's [i] very, very [/i] alpha; it'll be a while before it has a hope of catching up.

This game is work of bleeping genius! Perfect for the creative and/or technical minded gamer, for modders, people interested in rockets and outer space, and/or just for fun playing around with physics and blowing things up.
Basically its a sandbox solar system simulation with no story but rather different game modes. The career mode helps to provide direction at first and is the most educational for space novices. However, soon after that, its all up to you what you want to do. Career missions are optional, though will help motivate you to push further and further. Or you can just do whatever you want in the default sandbox mode with all the technology unlocked. The game is highly technical and doesnt hold your hand. There are various tutorials and scenarios that can help, but be prepared for a learning curve (though at your own pace). 
The physics aren't perfect, and distances between objects in the games simulated mini solar system is tiny compared to reality, but its still massive, with plenty to do. There are mods to make it more accurate and realistic (scale and detail wise), or to make it easier. Its completely up to the player.
As someone who has always been a casual sci-fi fan and earthbound spaceman my whole life, I think KSP has single-handedly taught me more about how space travel works then school, and books, movies, documentaries, etc. combined. And also given me a far greater appreciation for the efforts of early space pioneers as well as the current space programs and companies.
By doing things practically, you get to see and perform a lot of stuff that may otherwise just be concepts on paper and screen. Personally it has given me a far better fundamental understanding, particularly and especially when it comes to "orbits", but in many other ways. (Most of the time I enjoy just making ground vehicles, planes, drones, SSTOs, etc, and testing them out).
I could go on about all the ways I enjoy KSP, but in a nutshell, it's just an awesome game, and I honestly have so few criticisms that they seem irrelevant. I would happily give it 10/10, and I'm looking forward to playing KSP2!

Here's a recipe for Beef Wellington:

Ingredients:
- 1 (2-pound) beef tenderloin
- Salt and freshly ground black pepper
- 2 tablespoons Dijon mustard
- 1/2 pound mushrooms, finely chopped
- 1/4 cup chopped shallots
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 2 tablespoons unsalted butter
- 1/4 cup dry white wine
- 1/4 cup beef broth
- 1 tablespoon chopped fresh thyme leaves
- 1 sheet puff pastry, thawed
- 1 large egg, lightly beaten

Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F.
2. Season the beef tenderloin with salt and pepper.
3. Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the beef and sear on all sides until browned, about 2 minutes per side. Remove from the skillet and let cool.
4. Spread the Dijon mustard over the cooled beef tenderloin.
5. In the same skillet, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the mushrooms, shallots, and garlic and cook until the mushrooms are browned and the liquid has evaporated, about 10 minutes.
6. Add the white wine, beef broth, and thyme to the skillet and cook until the liquid has reduced by half, about 5 minutes.
7. Remove the skillet from the heat and let the mushroom mixture cool.
8. On a lightly floured surface, roll out the puff pastry to a thickness of 1/4 inch.
9. Spread the mushroom mixture over the puff pastry.
10. Place the beef tenderloin on top of the mushroom mixture.
11. Wrap the puff pastry around the beef tenderloin, making sure to seal the edges.
12. Brush the beaten egg over the top of the puff pastry.
13. Place the Beef Wellington on a baking sheet and bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the puff pastry is golden brown and the beef tenderloin is cooked to your liking.
14. Let the Beef Wellington rest for 10 minutes before slicing and serving.

Enjoy!

When former NASA engineer Randall Munroe, creator of xkcd comics, posts a short graph about how he learned more about orbital mechanics playing this game than he did actually working at NASA, it got my attention. And it's true, you really do learn a lot about aerospace engineering and a very simplified version of orbital mechanics in this game. It leaves you feeling empowered and wanting to actually go into the field. You don't just play this game, you join a community, and it changes your perspective on things.

In my opinion, KSP(Kerbal Space Program) is the best rocket game right now. Currently, there are 3 competitors to KSP. They are: Juno: New Origins, KSP 2, and Spaceflight Simulator. First, Juno: New Origins. This game used to be called "Simplerockets 2", and I can see why. It has no variety in parts (except for engines). It has only one fuel tank, separator, etc. KSP, though, has many different parts that are good for different situations. In terms of content besides the building, KSP has way more to do. The only good thing I can say about Juno is that it can run on a potato. Next, KSP 2. Right now, KSP 2 is worse than KSP in my opinion. It has better graphics, but not much else is better as far as I know. KSP 2 is new, though, so it will probably get better in the future. Finally, Spaceflight Simulator. This game can be described in 3 words: pay to win. It seems like every update to this game adds a new DLC. Without the DLC, it barely has anything. KSP has 2 DLC, but they arent needed to do good and have fun. In spaceflight simulator. basic parts (engines, fuel tanks) are behind a paywall, and you are only given the most basic parts.

Kerbal Space Program, developed by Squad, is a game that truly deserves all the awards it has received and more. From its realistic physics simulation to its charming and lovable characters, Kerbal Space Program is a game that will keep you coming back for more.

One of the standout features of Kerbal Space Program is its physics simulation. The game's mechanics are based on real-world physics, making it a great tool for learning about space travel and rocket science. And the game's sandbox mode allows players to experiment with different designs and strategies, creating a gameplay experience that is both educational and fun.

But what really sets Kerbal Space Program apart is its characters. The game's lovable and quirky Kerbals bring a much-needed sense of humor and heart to the simulation, making it a joy to play. And the game's slapstick humor and unexpected surprises keep the gameplay fresh and exciting.

Of course, no review of Kerbal Space Program would be complete without mentioning its incredible modding community. The game's active modding scene has created countless new features and gameplay mechanics, making it a game that you can play for years without getting bored.

All in all, Kerbal Space Program is a game that truly deserves all the awards it has received and more. If you're a fan of simulation games, space travel, or just great game design in general, then this is a game you simply can't miss.

I liked the concept, but won't endorse the greedy updates.

Stimulating, rewarding, enjoyable. KSP provides a solar system and current space technology. Sandbox mode lets you tinker with all the parts freely, while career mode gives context for performing "experiments" (launch a rocket to place X and perform experiment Y) which unlocks more spaceship parts to build with.

There's probes, rovers, landers, spacewalks, flybys, you name it. It's a very involving game, solving the problems of how to reach a planet, and slow down to land on it, even collecting a sample to bring back to the home planet. Ontop of being a fun game, KSP provides an easy way to grasp the concepts of early space travel, and it's not overly complicated. Just pick the right parts, and fire your rocket at the right time and direction to get somewhere. It suffers a stuttering issue for many people, but it's not a gamebreaker.

I did end up having issues with the later nonsense, like the RedShell debacle which soured my respect for the game as a product. They still want to sell it at £29.99 despite releasing a sequel. The DLC is expensive, and they added a pointless launcher that wants you to make some other account. This game was recommended to me as a spaceship simulator. I was trying to understand how it works and where the spaceship simulator is, but it is actually a space agency simulator, not a flight simulator as such. I was looking for something like rogue system or interkosmos 2000, but this nothing to do. In my case, I lost 8 hours trying to find the meaning of this game (I say this taking into account the expectation of wanting a spaceship flight simulator). I tried to return the game but since I've been playing for 8 hours, returns are no longer accepted. In the end I was disappointed and with a game that I don't want in my hands and the bad thing is that today with the gaming platforms there is no way to give it away to someone who is interested. Too bad, but what can you do? So as a reference this is not a space flight simulator (that is to say, it is not being behind the controls of a ship) it has nothing to do or is even comparable to games like interkosmos 2000 in (VR) or rogue system or even flight of nova. Those who are looking for something similar to those games are warned. This is not it.

Kerbal Space Program is a game that offers a unique and engaging experience for players who are interested in space exploration and rocket science. Developed by Squad, the game puts you in charge of a space program run by the green, humanoid Kerbals.

The game tasks you with designing and building spacecraft, launching them into orbit, and exploring the vast reaches of space. The game offers a sandbox mode where you can experiment with different designs and test your vehicles, as well as a career mode where you must manage your resources and complete missions to advance your space program.

One of the most impressive aspects of Kerbal Space Program is its realistic physics engine, which accurately simulates the forces and dynamics of space flight. This makes designing and building spacecraft a challenging but rewarding experience, as you must take into account factors such as thrust, weight, and aerodynamics.

The graphics of the game are also impressive, with detailed models of the Kerbals and their spacecraft, as well as beautiful depictions of the planets and moons in the game's universe. The sound effects and music are also well done, adding to the immersive experience.

Overall, Kerbal Space Program is a game that offers a unique and engaging experience for players who are interested in space exploration and rocket science. Its realistic physics engine, challenging gameplay, and impressive graphics make it a must-play for anyone who has ever dreamed of becoming an astronaut. If you're looking for a game that combines science, exploration, and fun, then Kerbal Space Program is definitely worth checking out.

This is a review from someone that has over 3000 hours on record and 100's of craft files between steam and kerbal x for download. 

This game has saved my creativity and desire for building Fighter jets, Real World Space Craft, Sci-fi Space Craft, Mechs, Wheeled Vehicles, Bases, Space Stations. Basically you name it, I've probably made it! If your like me and you grew up Building Craft, Lego's, Robotics, RC vehicles etc then this is the game for you no question! You seriously can do it all.

If you have a young child that is interested in any of the above and want to have something to push their creativity and inspire them later on in life to pursue those dreams. Get this game for them asap. (I wish I had something like this when I was younger!) 

This game is also good if you want something to chill out to if you play very serious games and want a break! 

You can build and upload your craft on the Workshop (come visit my page for lots of specialized craft) keeping it stock or if the uploaded craft requires a mod they generally will list it (I don't use mods for my downloads btw) There is also another popular website people upload their craft at which is (kerbalx dot com) (Interstellarkev is my user on here). There is a huge community out there and various Discords you can join to get help, tips, and inspiration.

This game does not require a super computer to run but it is challenging with FPS and loading if you start building over 1000 parts. This is a CPU dependent game. There are tons of graphical mods you can download to make things look more pretty if you would like to but you will need a GPU that has at least 8 GB Vram  to balance it out properly

Some of my favorite graphical mods are

Program CKAN (this will allow you to download mods from the internet without manually installing but some mods you may want to manual install. the rest you can find on the official kerbal space program forum)

Environmental Visual Enhancements Redux or (EVE REDUX for short)
Planet Shine
Waterfall
Scatter
TUFX
Textures Unlimited with Magpie and Textures Unlimited Recolour Depot (T.U.R.D) (this is to change color on parts)

I can't recommend this game enough. it's great. Factually better than the 2nd one as of right now. Worth the full price or buy it on sell if you must. The DLC is also worth it! If you can only buy 1 DLC I recommend the Breaking Grounds DLC btw as it adds robotic parts so you can make things like Mechs, Tanks, Sci-Fi Craft, General moving parts with hinges and pistons, Helicopters Propeller Planes etc. I have made a plethora of mechanical crafts.

Alright stop reading and buy it now!

Kerbal Space Program is a fantastic game that allows players to explore the universe in a fun and engaging way. The game's unique blend of simulation and sandbox gameplay makes it a joy to play, as players can experiment with different designs, technologies, and strategies to achieve their goals. The game's charming and quirky characters, the Kerbals, add a lot of personality to the experience, making it easy to become invested in their adventures. The game also has a fantastic modding community that adds even more content and depth to the experience, allowing players to further customize their gameplay. Overall, Kerbal Space Program is a must-play game for anyone who loves space exploration, simulation, or just having fun. It's an incredibly rewarding experience that will keep you coming back for more.

I have played this game for more than 85 hours, and would absolutely recommend it. I've played for a while, both moded instances and non moded and can say I have so much fun. The developers did an excellent job making the game challenging and enjoyable at the same time. 

I find myself spending hours in teh Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB) and then watching my rocket exploding into piecing because of a silly mistake I made. But after watching multiple failures and finally succeeding in landing on a moon or planet, I am filled with satisfaction of my hard work and planning. This is a gem and even though it was released in 2015 (post early access) you can still have so much fun! Pick it up, with any price tag.

If there ever was a game that could teach complicated techniques about space travel and orbital mechanics  that most of us think only the gifted have a firm grasp on understanding, in a simple, intuitive way that allows even the lowliest space enthusiast to easily comprehend; things such as gravity assists, planetary body gravity wells, or rendezvous (my favorite to try to explain to people) between two craft in orbit, then this is the game that has achieved it. If one is willing to put the time and patience into Kerbal Space Program, then they will come to learn a lot of the complicated techniques that space agencies around the world use to do the near impossible things in space that most of us take for granted. Things like putting rovers on Mars using a hohmann transfer or using multiple gravity assists just to get close enough to skirt the edge of the freakin' sun so us humans can get a sample of our glorious star. this game, KSP, Kerbal Space Program, Kerbal, will teach it all to you and a lot, lot more, and in a way that will educate you and excite you all at the same time. You will come to play a game about space, but you will walk away with a new found knowledge that will stay with you for the rest of your life. This truly is a game for the books, in more ways than one. The KSP way!

The choice of parts is extremely limited and there are no tools to diagnose problems, so there is no way to know why things happened to the vehicle. The choice for actions and stages are also very limited, which makes the choice of possible vehicles limited to a few existing designs. It is also very hard to test the vehicles as quick-saving at a specific point to repeat a specific part of the flight will remove the ability to revert back to editing the vehicle, so you are forced to land or crash. This means that when testing you would have to launch every time to reach a specific point, which becomes very tedious and time consuming. There are also no guides to all the building tools or information on anything related to the game such as aerodynamics and thrust.

This is an amazing game. You can genuinely learn quite a bit about rocket science, space travel, and physics from this game! It's a joy to play around with and create spacecraft. It does a good job of capturing the scale, the vastness, of space. Each mission is challenging. 

The only real problem with this game is the onboarding. Good heavens, this game doesn't teach you squat! The tutorial gives you the bare-bones basics to get to The Mun. I really must emphasis how bare-bones it is! There are TONS of keys that all do different things. The game doesn't tell you this. Some of these keys are kindof important, you know, like brakes! Trying to determine the best delta-v for a specific altitude because one of the game's missions asked you to? Good luck with that, game doesn't tell you! Pretty much everything in this game is a combination of Trial-and-Error and looking up videos/posts to learn from other people.

Regrettably, mods are almost a requirement. Not because the game is unplayable without them... it just needs the Quality of Life improvements that much.

It's a great game! Fun to play around with! However, to get the most out of it, you're gonna spend twice as long watching videos about [u]how[/u] to play the game than you will spend actually playing the game. Let's be honest here: that's a little rough. Kerbal Space Program could've done a lot better on this front and hopefully KSP2 will do better.

Steps to playing KSP
1.BUILD FLYING VEHICLE
2.blow up kerbals and plane
3.repeat steps 1 & 2 (at least 6 or 7 times)
4.SUCCEED!
5.have fun with rovers (kinda)
6.research...
7.play creative
8.install mods
9.blow up kerbals
10.give your computer a heart attack by using a workshop item
11.crash the game
12.install mods
13.spend 6 hours trying to figure out why the mod isn't working
14.fix the mod problem after realising you made a dumb mistake on installation
15.make something really cool
16.blow up more kerbals
17.get bored and maybe uninstall the game
18.suddenly want to play ksp again and reinstall
19.try to install some new mods
20.repeat steps 12,13&14
21.use a kerbal as a heat shield
22.danger zone!
23.try using robotics
24.fail at using robotics 
25.give up using robotics
26.actually figure out ksp functions
27.repeat steps 1-26

NOTE: by watching a tutorial you can skip most of these steps, or you can be like me and wing it until you kinda figure it out.

One of the best games that I ever decided to buy. I remember first playing this game at a science camp a long time ago, but it took a couple of years until I re-discovered the game through YouTube and decided to buy it. It ran on my impressively horrible laptop, and continues to work on my PC today. I have had so much fun playing this game, from building missions that have taken me to every planet and moon in the game, building giant space colonies on Minmus and space stations everywhere, space-planes, missiles, rovers, fighter jets, and so much more! You are really only limited by your imagination. This game has also really helped me enrich my interest in wanting to become an Aerospace Engineer. The amount of mods you can install for this game are incredible as well. Now that I have a decent amount of playtime in the game, and that it's final update has been released, I felt obliged to leave a review on this game. Here's to the success of KSP 2!

Generally recommend, especially those interested in orbital mechanics.However, there are several hangups that especially hurt coming from anything 'harder' in orbital mechanics than KSP, and a few things that are just bad regardless.Orbital eccentricity is only found in the map view, and in general none of your orbital parameters (even the most critical, like AP/PE altitudes) are in any place accessible. Forget LAN.Information in general is really lacking, fitting the 'throw something together, trial and error' game style. Acceleration? Guess. Weight? It'll kind of tell you, but it's like pulling teeth, especially if you want to compare it to anything. Batteries? Cool, I have power! No idea how long that charge will last, and good luck finding what the power use of anything is. The choice of Isp without exhaust velocity is personally annoying, but at least is in line with rocketry texts from the 50s.Maneuvering is actually generally intuitive, even in a simplified system, but has a few particularly annoying glitches. Most especially have fun trying to cancel a maneuver as the most reliable way isn't clicking the maneuver and then the X, it's fiddle with the bottom left mode setting to flip to orbit and back to maneuver to hit the X there because it desyncs what your map mode is.To summarize: It's a great game in its niche of reducing a complex topic to simplicity, but in a few areas it has been simplified to the point trial and error is not just the easiest way but nearly the only way to move forward. Add in some frustrating UI issues and of course the typical wonky collision physics module and you have a game that is merely good, rather than one that is great.

TL;DR Not without bugs, but easily one of the best space games ever. Get it if you're interested in spaceflight

Let's start with the bad:
- Bad performance, especially with larger craft and when using lots of mods
- Lots of memory leaks that can lead to crashes, again especially with mods
- Missing some things that as a veteran i consider essential quality of life (there are mods to help with that, but some things should be in the base game)
- Lackluster graphics
- Limited practical use of planetary bases or space stations

For me personally, all of these can be forgiven, as you can see by my hours. And that's not counting the thousands of hours used off Steam. Because:
- Beyond rockets, you can also build spacestations and even ships; you can also construct craft in orbit.
- KSP uses real physics (mostly)
- ...while still being easy to pick up and a ton of fun. That's incredibly impressive given the above.
- Similarly, it's very educational. While the solar system in the game is a dramatically scaled down version of our solar system, you will get a basic intuitive understanding of how orbits work, how interplanetary works and so on that mostly apply to the real world
- Great moddability, giving plenty of replayability. Realism Overhaul in particular can keep you busy for thousands of hours by removing the training wheels and getting the game much closer to reality, which also means it is much harder, giving even veterans a challenge.
- It's a great example for a sandbox game. You can just play around and build silly rockets. You can be serious and try to land on all the bodies (that you can) in one single launch. You can play a career where failure has consequences. Or install mods to add more solar systems, more parts, more realism, ... . There is plenty to do, and plenty of ways to keep the game fresh, especially with mods.

Overall, if you're interested in spaceflight at all, this is pretty much The game to get. The worst issues with KSP are on the technical side and with the engine it uses; otherwise the game is fantastic. You don't have to be super into science to be able to enjoy it, although it certainly helps if you approach the game through a science lens if you want to achieve certain milestones like landing on other planets. Personally, it's what inspired me to learn a lot more about spaceflight and you'll hear many similar stories of other KSP players. It's without a doubt one of the best games i ever played, it made me learn some real science while having fun and some of my favourite gaming moments ever have been in KSP. That first Moon Landing with Realism Overhaul is something i will never forget.

If you like vehicle building, space, rocketry, or all of the above, this game is for you. The following are some prominent game play features within the game:

-Simple to learn, hard to master vehicle building
-Simulated physics
-Real life rocketry concepts
-The ability to build rockets, satellites, rovers, space stations, planetary and lunar space stations, planes, helicopters, etc...
-3 distinct modes with multiple difficulties (and custom sliders to modify game play)
-Missions to assist with your creative endeavors 
-massive mod support
-ability to import other creators vehicles via workshop (and other means)

Although this game does suffer from being rough around the edges sometimes (kracken) it's a fantastic game with an insane amount of content worth the price.

3 activities that bring great joy are: Making things, piloting things really fast, and blowing things up.  This game allows you to do all that and also learn a thing or two about rocket science and astrophysics along the way.  You are limited only by your creativity and the cold iron hand of physics (which has bcome very adept at swatting down lofty ambitions).

Beginners will thrill at finally escaping the atmosphere, intermediate players will find joy in assembling thier first space refuling  station, advanced players will install mods to make the game 10x harder and still show everyone up on YouTube, and Scott Manley will become a household name.

Customizable diffuculty and multiple play settings means you can be as Buck Rogers or NASA as you like, and there is a deep pool of mods to further tailor your experience.

The ultimate space-craft simulator. Scientifically accurate enough for those who deeply care, but also complete sandbox possibilities for those who just want to build random stuff and see if it works. It's an old game, but also timeless in its design, and there are definitely mods available to make the game look more to today's standards (if you care for that). Plus it never gets old seeing a kerbal smile when entering space for the first time (and then crash-landing and killing them in the process xD). Game could be overwhelming at first, and will harshly punish you for getting things wrong, but give it some time and before you know it, you won't be able to stop to make that one final adjustment to do the perfect run.

Oh KSP where do I begin... As you can tell by my many hours in this game, I have very much enjoyed it. I have gotten so much use out of this simple(ish) simulator game. There is a fairly sizable learning curve in the beginning but that shouldn't scare off any new players because of how satisfying progression is. With the recent release of KSP 2 in an unfinished state I have heard many people say that it is a steaming heap of rubbish, and I somewhat agree. I believe that the future of KSP 2 is very bright but for the time being it is slightly underwhelming. If there are any new KSP players out there dissapointed by KSP 2, then please buy the original and give it a shot. The original KSP is a very well rounded game that can give you experience for when the sequel is in a playable state. This game has inspired me to take up a career in aeronautical engineering because of how fun it was to design aircraft in this game. I hope you can get as much as I did from this amazing game. Thank You for reading this, and have a wonderful day.

Kerbal Space Program is an amazing game that does an incredible job of introducing the complex world of rocket science to players who may have little to no experience in the subject. From designing and building your own rockets to planning and executing missions to explore the vast universe around you, Kerbal Space Program offers an immersive and engaging experience that is both educational and entertaining.

What sets Kerbal Space Program apart from other games is its focus on real-world physics and mechanics. The game doesn't just let you blast off into space without a second thought; it requires you to carefully plan and execute your missions, taking into account things like thrust, fuel consumption, and gravity. This level of detail may seem overwhelming at first, but the game does an excellent job of breaking everything down into manageable chunks and guiding you through the process step-by-step.

The game's lovable characters, the Kerbals, also add a fun and quirky element to the game. These little green creatures are your crew members, and they have their own unique personalities and abilities that can affect the success of your missions. Watching them bounce around in zero gravity or celebrating a successful launch is incredibly rewarding and makes the game even more enjoyable.

Overall, Kerbal Space Program is an amazing game that offers a unique and engaging way to learn about rocket science and space exploration. Whether you're a seasoned space enthusiast or just looking for a fun and educational game to play, Kerbal Space Program is definitely worth checking out.

Kerbal Space Program is a fantastic game that will take you on an amazing journey through the depths of space. From the very start, you are tasked with designing your own spacecraft and launching it into the great unknown. With its intuitive controls and realistic physics engine, you'll find yourself immersed in an experience unlike any other.

But what really sets Kerbal Space Program apart is the sense of accomplishment you'll feel with each successful launch. Whether you're sending a probe to explore a distant planet or landing on the moon, each step of the journey feels like a true achievement. And with the ability to share your successes with other players, the sense of community and camaraderie is truly unparalleled.

Overall, I highly recommend Kerbal Space Program to anyone who loves space exploration, engineering, or just plain fun. It's a game that will challenge you, inspire you, and keep you coming back for more. So if you're ready to blast off into the final frontier, give Kerbal Space Program a try - you won't be disappointed!
